awd_titl_txt: Exploring the link between re-reading and comprehension
awd_abstract_narration:
When people have trouble understanding what they are reading, they tend to go back and re-read a portion of the text. In other words, your eyes don't continuously move left to right when reading English. Instead, your eye movements are often interrupted as you return to look at one or more previously read portions of the text. It has been assumed that returning to earlier parts of a sentence helps the reader understand the text. Although reading an entire text multiple times does result in a more detailed understanding, no studies have yet shown that readers' selective backwards eye movements are related to specific corrections of earlier misinterpretations or even to more accurate understanding. It is also not known how individual readers differ with respect to how they re-read, or whether individual strategies or patterns of re-reading behavior are related to better reading comprehension. Reading is fundamental to learning, education, and daily life and reading difficulties can hinder learning in all areas. Thus, understanding how real-time reading behaviors relate to comprehension is critically important.

During normal, skilled silent reading, approximately 15% of eye movements return to earlier portions of the text (i.e., they are "regressive"). Regressions are typically triggered by some sort of disruption to the normal forward progress through the text and subsequent re-reading is typically interpreted as a reanalysis, revision, or reprocessing of some or all of the previously read text. This reprocessing is generally taken as an indication that the reader has derived a more accurate, grammatically licensed interpretation. However, in the psycholinguistic and reading literatures, the actual affect of these re-reading behaviors on comprehension has been largely assumed.  Moreover, studies have not linked the various aspects of re-reading (location of regressions, scan paths during re-reading, time spent re-reading, as so on) to accuracy rates on comprehension probes of the type often used in educational assessments of reading comprehension. The proposed project includes three series of eye-tracking experiments that examine (1) the triggers for regressions; (2) the type of reprocessing performed during re-reading; (3) the influence of re-reading on reading comprehension; and (4) individual differences in working memory capacity and reading fluency on re-reading and text comprehension. The proposed project is a large-scale systematic exploration of the fundamental assumption that re-reading enhances comprehension. The results of the proposed work will inform the fields of psycholinguistics, psychology, reading, education, linguistics, and STEM instruction -- indeed, any area that relies on extracting complex information from text.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Three large-scale eye-tracking studies were undertaken during the award peirod (including 1 year of no-cost extension), comprising 5 experiments with a total number of participants of approximately 750. The first two experiments have been combined in one very large manuscript, which is under revision for resubmission for publication. The second experiment is a stand-alone study that is currinently being written up for submisison. The final two experiments are planned to be combined in a third manuscript. All experiments were conducted using novel paradigms that are methodologically innovative, and report data that fundamentally alter the psycholinguistic understanding of rereading behaviors and their link to comprehension. These results are of interest to the wider cognitive science community, as well as to reading reaserchers who seek to model eye movement behaviors during normal silent reading. The final experiment, which incorporates auditory perceptual simulation (APS) during reading promises to also be of interest to educational researchers who develop interventions for struggling readers. Due to the pandemic, completion of the final experiment was delayed, but it is being completed with the PI's personal research funds. In addition to the expected publications, various stages of these studies have been presented at several international conferences. All presentations and publications include 3-4 doctoral student co-authors. Four doctoral students were supported fully or partially by the NSF funding. One of these defended a few years ago, one defended last year, and two more will defend in Spring, 2022.


Last Modified: 09/09/2021
Modified by: Kiel Christianson
